ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: HyperNEAT Outputs for Stock Trading
ygData.msgSnippet: There are other benefits to HyperNEAT that have nothing to do with geometry, no? It is an indirect encoding, and thus is more likely to create modular

There are other benefits to HyperNEAT that have nothing to do with geometry,
no? It is an indirect encoding, and thus is more likely to create modular
phenotypes that exhibit repetitions and symmetry (with and without
variation).

Unless I am mistaken, these benefits can cause HyperNEAT to outperform NEAT
even on problems where geometry is not being exploited. Does that sound
right to everyone?





Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...




> From: petar_chervenski <petar_chervenski@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Wed, 14 May 2008 21:22:45 -0000
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] Re: HyperNEAT Outputs for Stock Trading
> 
> Well I don't understand what does HyperNEAT to do with it. Unless you
> believe there is some geometric regularities in those time series
> there is no point to use HyperNEAT. Try regular NEAT first.
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Todd Owen" <jtoddowen@...> wrote:
>> 
>> My goal is to evolve a stock trader.  The inputs are various
> technical
>> indicators, but I like the output to indicate five states--Buy/Sell
>> (going long), Short/Cover (going short), and do nothing.  Ideally,
>> each signal would be a 1 or 0 (all zeros indicates to do nothing
> (i.e.
>> keep current position - long, short, or out).
>> 
>> 1. Is this best framed as a classification problem (now is a good
> time
>> to buy, sell, short, cover), or would some type of 0-1 analog output
>> be best (meaning buy when buy is > sell by 0.2 or something)?  How
> do
>> you force a binary output in the software anyway?
>> 
>> 2. Should I try to predict the percentage change (up or down) over
> the
>> next n time periods, and then only buy or sell when there is say a
> 3%
>> change from now?
>> 
>> 3. when recurrence evolves in NEAT, does it look back only 1 time
>> period, or can it evolve longer lookbacks?
>> 
>> --Thanks, Todd
>> 
> 
>
